articles.headline: Trump Says Little on Gaza, and Nothing About What He’d Do Differently
articles.snippet: Donald Trump’s approach to the bloody Mideast conflict reflects the anti-interventionist shift he has brought about in Republican politics — and his personal feelings about the Israeli prime minister.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump’s approach to the bloody Mideast conflict reflects the anti-interventionist shift he has brought about in Republican politics — and his personal feelings about the Israeli prime minister.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the nearly five months since Hamas terrorists invaded Israel on Oct. 7, igniting the most divisive foreign policy crisis of the Biden presidency, Donald J. Trump has said noticeably little about the subject.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Michael Gold

articles.headline: Unemployment Casts a Shadow Over California’s Economy
articles.snippet: Tech layoffs, fallout from Hollywood strikes and an uptick in rural joblessness challenge a state with one of the nation’s highest unemployment rates.
articles.abstract: Tech layoffs, fallout from Hollywood strikes and an uptick in rural joblessness challenge a state with one of the nation’s highest unemployment rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: For decades, California’s behemoth economy has outpaced those of most nations, holding an outsize role in shaping global trends in tech, entertainment and agriculture.

articles.headline: Witnesses of Aid Convoy Violence Describe Shooting, Panic and Desperation
articles.snippet: “I saw people falling to the ground after being shot,” said one witness, “and others simply took the food items that were with them and continued running for their lives.”
articles.abstract: “I saw people falling to the ground after being shot,” said one witness, “and others simply took the food items that were with them and continued running for their lives.”
articles.lead_paragraph: They went out by the thousands, camping overnight along a coastal road in the cold Gaza night, huddled together by small fires, waiting for supplies to come so they could feed their families.
articles.byline: By Raja Abdulrahim, Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Adam Rasgon and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: In Rancho Cucamonga, a Team of Teenage Tax Slayers Helps Adults
articles.snippet: At a high school in California, students help run a tax-return clinic. They get academic credit, breakfast burritos and life lessons.
articles.abstract: At a high school in California, students help run a tax-return clinic. They get academic credit, breakfast burritos and life lessons.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Saturdays at Rancho Cucamonga High School, the indoor-outdoor campus can resemble a community carnival.

articles.headline: Paramedic Sentenced to Five Years in Death of Elijah McClain
articles.snippet: The case was a rare prosecution of medical personnel that stirred strong reaction from paramedics following the case.
articles.abstract: The case was a rare prosecution of medical personnel that stirred strong reaction from paramedics following the case.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Colorado paramedic convicted in the 2019 death of Elijah McClain, a young Black man whose case helped drive the national police reform movement, was sentenced on Friday to five years in prison.
articles.byline: By Audra D. S. Burch and Kelley Manley

articles.headline: Big Labor Gamble: Push to Unionize Every U.S. Auto Plant
articles.snippet: A looming election at a Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga could be pivotal in the United Automobile Workers’ effort to organize the entire industry.
articles.abstract: A looming election at a Volkswagen plant in Chattanooga could be pivotal in the United Automobile Workers’ effort to organize the entire industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Shawn Fain, the United Automobile Workers president, unveiled the deal that ended six weeks of strikes at Ford Motor in the fall, he framed it as part of a longer campaign. Next, he declared, would be the task of organizing nonunion plants across the country.

articles.headline: Why Some Colombians Call Their Mothers ‘Your Mercy’
articles.snippet: Two centuries after independence from Spain, many Colombians still use “sumercé,” meaning “your mercy” as an everyday address.
articles.abstract: Two centuries after independence from Spain, many Colombians still use “sumercé,” meaning “your mercy” as an everyday address.
articles.lead_paragraph: After Altair Jaspe moved from Venezuela to the Colombian capital, Bogotá, she was taken aback by the way she was addressed when she walked into any shop, cafe or doctor’s office.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz and Nathalia Angarita

articles.headline: Voters Doubt Biden’s Leadership and Favor Trump, Times/Siena Poll Finds
articles.snippet: The share of voters who strongly disapprove of President Biden’s handling of his job has reached 47 percent, higher than in Times/Siena polls at any point in his presidency.
articles.abstract: The share of voters who strongly disapprove of President Biden’s handling of his job has reached 47 percent, higher than in Times/Siena polls at any point in his presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden is struggling to overcome doubts about his leadership inside his own party and broad dissatisfaction over the nation’s direction, leaving him trailing behind Donald J. Trump just as their general-election contest is about to begin, a new poll by The New York Times and Siena College has found.

articles.headline: The Paradox at the Heart of Elon Musk’s OpenAI Lawsuit
articles.snippet: Mr. Musk says in his complaint that the company’s technology is now so good that it must be made freely available to the public — and held back from Microsoft.
articles.abstract: Mr. Musk says in his complaint that the company’s technology is now so good that it must be made freely available to the public — and held back from Microsoft.
articles.lead_paragraph: It would be easy to dismiss Elon Musk’s lawsuit against OpenAI as a case of sour grapes.

articles.headline: Lack of Plan for Governing Gaza Formed Backdrop to Deadly Convoy Chaos
articles.snippet: Israel has no clear plan for governing Gaza. That is a particular problem in the north, where the fighting has ebbed, and where a deadly stampede occurred on Thursday around an aid convoy.
articles.abstract: Israel has no clear plan for governing Gaza. That is a particular problem in the north, where the fighting has ebbed, and where a deadly stampede occurred on Thursday around an aid convoy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israel’s reluctance to fill the current leadership vacuum in northern Gaza formed the backdrop to the chaos that led to the deaths on Thursday of dozens of Palestinians on the Gazan coast, analysts and aid workers have said.

articles.headline: The I.R.S.’s Taxpayer Experience Officer Says Open Your Mail Already
articles.snippet: Ken Corbin is fixing the phone lines — but those foreboding letters are staying the same.
articles.abstract: Ken Corbin is fixing the phone lines — but those foreboding letters are staying the same.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service is on a charm offensive, as long as you don’t earn too much money.

articles.headline: Majority of Biden’s 2020 Voters Now Say He’s Too Old to Be Effective
articles.snippet: A New York Times/Siena College poll revealed how much even his supporters worry about his age, intensifying what has become a grave threat to his re-election bid.
articles.abstract: A New York Times/Siena College poll revealed how much even his supporters worry about his age, intensifying what has become a grave threat to his re-election bid.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on Trump and Haley after Super Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Ruth Igielnik

articles.headline: Kremlin Seeks to Suppress Navalny’s Influence, in Death as in Life
articles.snippet: The Russian authorities vilified the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny with a viciousness that suggested he was more influential than Moscow would admit. Little has changed since he died.
articles.abstract: The Russian authorities vilified the opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny with a viciousness that suggested he was more influential than Moscow would admit. Little has changed since he died.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Aleksei A. Navalny was alive, the Kremlin sought to portray him as an inconsequential figure unworthy of attention, even as the Russian authorities vilified and attacked him with a viciousness that suggested the opposite.
articles.byline: By Paul Sonne and Oleg Matsnev

articles.headline: How Regulations Fractured Apple’s App Store
articles.snippet: As the App Store approaches its 16th anniversary, patchwork rules have turned what was a single store into different shops across many countries.
articles.abstract: As the App Store approaches its 16th anniversary, patchwork rules have turned what was a single store into different shops across many countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since introducing the App Store in 2008, Apple has run it largely the same way across 175 countries, right down to the 30 percent commission it has collected on every app sold.

articles.headline: Forced to Change: Tech Giants Bow to Global Onslaught of Rules
articles.snippet: For years, Apple, Google, Meta and others operated unfettered. But new laws and regulations have finally compelled them to make major shifts to their products and businesses.
articles.abstract: For years, Apple, Google, Meta and others operated unfettered. But new laws and regulations have finally compelled them to make major shifts to their products and businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: By Thursday, Google will have changed how it displays certain search results. Microsoft will no longer have Windows customers use its Bing internet search tool by default. And Apple will give iPhone and iPad users access to rival app stores and payment systems for the first time.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and David McCabe

articles.headline: The ZIP Code Shift: Why Many Americans No Longer Live Where They Work
articles.snippet: A new study shows that white-collar employees who can work remotely now live roughly twice as far from their offices as they did prepandemic.
articles.abstract: A new study shows that white-collar employees who can work remotely now live roughly twice as far from their offices as they did prepandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2020, Virginia Martin lived two and a half miles from her office. Today, the distance between her work and home is 156.

articles.headline: Biden vs. Trump: The Looming Rematch Hits a ‘Kickoff’ Moment
articles.snippet: Both campaigns view this week, with Super Tuesday and the State of the Union, as a critical period that will set the tone and define the early contours of the coming general election campaign.
articles.abstract: Both campaigns view this week, with Super Tuesday and the State of the Union, as a critical period that will set the tone and define the early contours of the coming general election campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden’s advisers are eager for the coming general-election fight and counting on voters to start paying more attention to Donald J. Trump, with the president himself even proposing and dashing off videos to ridicule the things his Republican rival says.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Apple Fined $2 Billion by E.U. for Using App Store to Thwart Competition
articles.snippet: Apple said it would appeal the penalty, the latest in a series of regulatory setbacks for the tech giant.
articles.abstract: Apple said it would appeal the penalty, the latest in a series of regulatory setbacks for the tech giant.
articles.lead_paragraph: Apple on Monday was fined 1.8 billion euros ($1.95 billion) by European Union regulators for thwarting competition among music streaming rivals, a severe punishment levied against the tech giant in a long-simmering battle over the powerful role it plays as gatekeeper of the App Store.
articles.byline: By Tripp Mickle and Adam Satariano

articles.headline: JetBlue and Spirit Call Off Their $3.8 Billion Merger
articles.snippet: JetBlue said it would pay Spirit $69 million to terminate the deal, which federal antitrust regulators blocked.
articles.abstract: JetBlue said it would pay Spirit $69 million to terminate the deal, which federal antitrust regulators blocked.
articles.lead_paragraph: JetBlue Airways and Spirit Airlines announced on Monday that they would not seek to overturn a court ruling that blocked their planned $3.8 billion merger. The decision is a big win for the Biden administration, which has sough to limit corporate consolidation.

articles.headline: Joe Biden’s Superfans Think the Rest of America Has Lost Its Mind
articles.snippet: Bewildered by tepid enthusiasm for a president they see as transformative, these Democrats occupy a lonely place in U.S. politics: “I feel like I’m the only one.”
articles.abstract: Bewildered by tepid enthusiasm for a president they see as transformative, these Democrats occupy a lonely place in U.S. politics: “I feel like I’m the only one.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on Trump and Haley after Super Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien, Katie Glueck and Michelle Gustafson

articles.headline: Trump Prevails in Supreme Court Challenge to His Eligibility
articles.snippet: The justices ruled that the 14th Amendment did not allow Colorado to bar the former president from the state’s primary ballot.
articles.abstract: The justices ruled that the 14th Amendment did not allow Colorado to bar the former president from the state’s primary ballot.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that states may not bar former President Donald J. Trump from running for another term, rejecting a challenge from Colorado to his eligibility that threatened to upend the presidential race by taking him off ballots around the nation.
